message.content:
We can “derive” the balance‐sheet “taxes payable” by (a) noticing that at the beginning of the period no taxable transaction had yet been recorded (so no opening liability) and (b) that each sale transaction “collects” a tax amount. In this exercise we scan the transactions for those of type “Sale” that record a nonblank tax_amount. (Other types – such as Purchases, Expenses, Interest, etc. – have no tax entries and therefore do not change the tax liability.) 

Going through the data we pick out the following “Sale” rows and their tax_amount values:

 • Sale20240103004:                 640.42  
 • Sale20240104005:                 5515.25  
 • Sale20240104006:                 13084.81  
 • Sale20240105008:                 5748.65  
 • Sale20240105009:                 1696.18  
 • Sale20240106010:                 5525.31  
 • Sale20240106011:                 1666.96  
 • Sale20240107013:                 2218.12  
 • Sale20240108015:                 19125.74  
 • Sale20240108016:                 26769.65  
 • Sale20240109018:                 9478.70  
 • Sale20240110019:                 15250.40  
 • Sale20240112020:                 2575.58  
 • Sale20240113021:                 15241.09  
 • Sale20240113022:                 5597.73  
 • Sale20240114024:                 33551.75  
 • Sale20240115026:                 1180.23  
 • Sale20240116028:                 1375.56  
 • Sale20240116029:                 2064.50  
 • Sale20240117032:                 2361.70  
 • Sale20240117033:                 9942.99  
 • Sale20240118034:                 32431.18  
 • Sale20240118035:                 3406.26  
 • Sale20240119036:                 2509.99  
 • Sale20240120038:                 3403.90  
 • Sale20240120039:                 656.45  
 • Sale20240121040:                 20715.81  
 • Sale20240122041:                 3295.12  
 • Sale20240123043:                 13465.34  
 • Sale20240123044:                 2628.39  
 • Sale20240124046:                 34276.22  
 • Sale20240125047:                 12186.71  
 • Sale20240126048:                 550.66  
 • Sale20240127049:                 8651.79  
 • Sale20240127050:                 2011.21  
 • Sale20240128052:                 5277.00  
 • Sale20240129053:                 28918.70  
 • Sale20240130056:                 6413.96  
 • Sale20240130057:                 3715.01  

Adding these values one by one (see detailed “step‐by‐step” accumulation above) we get a total tax amount of 365125.02. 

Since no tax liability existed initially (the “Initial” transactions do not record any tax payable), the “Taxes Payable” at the beginning is 0.00; then, after recording all these sales on which the tax was “collected” (and is owed to the taxing authority) the ending balance is 365125.02.

Thus the answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Taxes Payable Initial Value": "0.00",
    "Taxes Payable End Value": "365125.02"
  }
}

Note: In this exercise we assume that only “Sale” transactions generate a tax (with a nonzero tax_amount field) and that no adjustments (such as tax credits from purchases) are recorded.
